segments.text: For over a month, he had already been in a foreign country, changed his name and language to one that almost none of his friends thought he knew.
He grew a beard and wore a faded beret on his head.
If any of his acquaintances had met him, they would pass by without recognizing him.
His small apartment was in a middle-class area.
Most people had cars by their homes, even if not new and luxurious.
His car was also not large, gray in color, not flashy.
His entire appearance and conduct blended completely into the surrounding landscape.
He was immersed in his secret mission, aware that it would take a long time, but at night he dreamt about it, flooded with longing for his rosy girl.
He knew she was probably also at a loss, missing him, lacking any information, and not understanding where he suddenly disappeared to just when such a great and genuine love had ignited between them.
Sometimes he would close his eyes tightly.
Trying to send her strength and patience.
He once read a book about the power of mental intention.
He wanted her to know he loved her, to have the patience to wait, to know the absolute trust she gave him was not in vain.
It wasn't in his nature to believe in such communications, but with no other option left, he held on to this and hoped.
He knew that in four months, she would be discharged from the army.
He had no idea what she planned to do next.
So many secrets and unclear things that she hadn't yet had time to tell him stood between them.
He knew only one thing, that she was the one he wanted to share his life with.
Never before had he felt like this.
And at this time, both were forced to pause their lives for a period of unknown length, hoping that when he returns to her they can continue exactly where they left off.
What does she think?
How can one deal with the uncertainty and frustration that it creates?
Trust me, he said in his heart again and again.
Trust me.
At night, she dreamt of Dan seeing him in uniform with camouflage on his face, lifting his head to her for a moment and looking deep into her eyes like he did before leaving.
What did his looks say to her?
Suddenly he changed form in her dream, and she saw him sitting in a cafe in a foreign city with a strange hat on his head.
A glass of drink was before him, and he took it and brought it to his lips.
Then he raised his head again and looked deep into her eyes, as if trying to tell her something.
I trust you, she answered something to him, and instantly he vanished from her dream.
She awoke and glanced at the clock beside her.
It was three in the morning.
She sank into thoughts, trying to hold on to him and his eyes that looked so deep into hers.
How does it happen that the lives of two strangers become so intertwined in such a short time as if they were meant to be together?
She knew she couldn't give him up.
Her life was complicated and very challenging, but she could handle it.
She was not afraid.
She just wanted to be together with him.
From the moment he first touched her hand in the jeep, she felt that some of her great loneliness disappeared, as if from now on she was two, and two is so much more than alone.
Only the unknown drove her crazy.
She knew that if possible, the battalion commander would have shared with her.
The only thing he was ready to tell her was that it would take a long time.
But how long is a long time?
A month?
Two months?
And maybe much longer than that.
She wearily closed her eyes and opened them again at the sound of birds chirping.
The garden was the place where she occupied herself to avoid troubling thoughts.
She knelt, weeding, digging small pits around the flowers, opening and closing sprinklers.
Each time in a different part of the large garden, and after a few hours, she drank a large glass of water and sat in the shade with the book she was reading at the time.
From the edge of the garden, Andy Williams' deep voice was heard singing somewhere over the rainbow through her neighbor Carmela's open window, and slowly she completely immersed herself in the book.
Suddenly, she heard a throat clearing.
She raised her head and realized that without noticing, the book had fallen on her while she was dosing.
You see, the postman stood beside her smiling.
Hello, haven't seen you in a while.
How are you?
What about you?
I brought you some mail.
He handed her a small stack of letters.
Thank you, Yossi," she said.
Everything's fine.
I'm still in the army and dad's fine.
He lives in Tel Aviv.
Want something to drink?
He smiled, remembering Lucy, who always offered him a drink when he arrived.
The girl is just like her mother.
I'd love a cup of tea, thank you.
I've been walking around for hours and my legs remind me I'm not 16 anymore.
She laughed and got up to make him some tea.
Sit and rest on the lounge chair.
She returned from the house with a cup of tea and some cookies and a glass of water for herself to quench her thirst.
Yossi thanked her.
You managed to keep your mom's garden even better than her.
This garden looks like paradise and the hedge has grown so much.
It seems to embrace it all around, hiding it from the eyes of passersby and adding a mysterious touch.
Only those curious enough to peek between the tall bushes get to see the myriad blooms of pansies, sweet peas, and silver lace along the path.
And it's heartwarming.
Well done.
She looked at Yossi in awe.
He described the garden almost like a poet.
Maybe instead of delivering letters, he should write them.
You might find it strange.
She smiled at him.
But since mom passed away, I always feel like she's watching over me from above, making sure her garden doesn't wither.

I always think I wouldn't want to make her sad with a garden whose flowers wilt and grass yellows, and if she really is looking from above, at least she should be happy that the garden blooms tall and proud.
I think it helps you cope with missing her.
You had a unique mother, not like most mothers, and you should keep her memory alive in every way.
Pensively, she thought about his words.
He was right.
Her mother was unique.
Beautiful, smart, warm, spoke countless languages with anyone she met from some faraway country.
But most of all, she was her dearest mom.
How she would love for her to hold her now in a comforting and calming hug, to free her if only for a few minutes from the need to be grown up.
She wanted to curl up like the carefree, happy little girl she once was.
She lifted her gaze to Yossi the postman and found him looking at her.
They exchanged a gentle smile.
He probably misses Lucy too.
She encounters it occasionally.
people who regularly passed by the pink house over the years, Miss Lucy, as if they hoped to find her in some corner of the house.
Maybe she'll come out of the kitchen, light a cigarette and sit with them for a heartfelt chat.
I'm glad to see you're okay.
Yossi suddenly told her, I heard from the chef that you're managing this hotel all by yourself during your military service and doing the work that several employees used to do.
And I see he was right.
The house looks tidy, clean and cared for.
I'm just saying that if your mom is watching from above, she's very proud.
Now I have to continue on my way.
Thanks for the break with the tea and cookies.
It was refreshing.
He gathered his bag, slung it over his shoulder, and left.
After he left.
She sunk into thoughts.
Sometimes she wondered what people thought of her.
It's a small town.
Everyone is in each other's lives.
Everyone knows everyone.
She was probably a topic of conversation or gossip for those who love to engage in it.
What do they say?
What do they think?
Not everyone knew, of course.
She wasn't around too much.
And on her long weekends, she was busy with cleaning and tidying.
During the quiet hours, she was mostly with a book or by the piano, with herself.
The only ones who see her weekly are Albert the Grocer and Moshe the Butcher.
And they won't say a word.
They love her, care for her, and respect her insistence not to owe them a pound.
They're simple and good people who have known her since she was a little girl.
They also loved Lucy very much, to be fair.
They love yourself very much too.
One can't take that from him.
He's quite a character.
She was blessed with such special parents and her dear father with all his whims and sometimes irresponsibility is full of warmth and love with a great passion for life.
He loves her with all his soul, making her feel wonderful, and above all, appreciates and respects her love of books and music, and her sense, practicality, and responsibility.
Since she could remember, she'd hear him joke, I have a daughter with common sense.
She missed him.
Maybe he would come and take charge as nature dictates.
But in their case, nature got a little confused and reversed, and she was the one who understood him and let him be.
He lives with a partner who isn't to her liking, undoubtedly a bit unbalanced.

She doesn't understand how he ended up with her, thinking maybe it was a calculated decision, looking for someone with her own apartment and a good financial situation to free him from livelihood worries.
It's not that he doesn't work.
He manages a nice cafe, but it doesn't require too much.
He's returned to painting on their apartment balcony, and his life is easy.
She knows he wanted her to come live with them, but that didn't succeed, and after a while, she left.

Thus began her journey of alone, lots of alone, the kind that sometimes chokes in the throat, without knowing exactly what intensifies it at a certain moment, a smell, a picture, countless books read in an attempt to escape reality.
And yet she often felt as if both were with her, trying to envelop her.
She took Yossi the Postman's tea cup and her book, intending to return to the dining room.
And as she made her way in, the phone began to ring.
She hastily put everything down and ran to the phone.
Sure, the doctor was returning a call.
Hello, she said, perhaps too loudly.
Hello, answered a deep male voice.
It wasn't the doctor, she was sure.
She knew the voice, but couldn't recall to whom it belonged.
Hi, he said.
It's David, Dan's father.
I'm in the area on business and thought to see if you're home and if I could come by.
Of course, she thought to herself, it was the deep voice of Father David.
How strange that after all these months, just when feelings of loneliness and future anxieties were nearly overwhelming her.
He somehow sensed it and called.
Hello, David, she responded happily.
Certainly, I'd love that.
Do you know how to get here?
Yes, he replied.
Straight to the pink house.
They explained it to me.
I'll be there within half an hour.
In the time it took her to comb her hair and wash the few dishes in the sink, he was already at the door.
As she stepped toward him, a broad smile spread across her face, and in seconds he gathered her into a big hug.
How are you?"
he asked, looking at her.
You look a bit tired, but besides that, you look great.
Are you eating properly?
Funny, she thought to herself.
Why do they always ask if she's eating properly?
She surely knows how to take care of herself and feed a few more hungry ones around.
I'm doing fine.
Just missing some good sleep, but otherwise everything's okay.
Can I offer you coffee, something to eat?
Without hesitating, I'd be happy with both.
Hurry to you and skip the meal offered.
He trailed after her to the kitchen, watching her as she prepared a roast beef sandwich with a pickle and sliced some vegetables on the side.
Perhaps you'd like a beer with it.
Great, he replied.
They sat on the high chairs by the bar, side by side in silence.
He bit hungrily into the sandwich she made and sip the beer she poured him.
She also held a glass of beer, filled with water, drinking large gulps, quenching her almost constant thirst.
After he finished, he wiped his mouth with a napkin, took another sip of beer, and turned to her with a very serious expression on his face.
Don't think I know more than you, he said.
He disappeared overnight from us too, called and only said, Don't worry, it'll take time, but I'll be back.
Naomi worries so much.
Doesn't sleep at night.
Just wants to.
No, he's okay.
And so do I. We men may seem tougher, but it's probably just theoretical.
I meet her in the kitchen at night when I get up for something to drink, and we spend time together until morning begins and a new day starts.
He didn't share with us what's happening between you, but I could see in his eyes and the way he spoke about you that you went deep into his heart.
If this ordeal lasts, I want you to know we're here for you, with and without connection to Dan.
Despite all my extensive connections, I can't get even a hint of where he's vanished to.
I only know he has all those traits needed for such covert operations and I trust him.
It's so strange, she thought, as if he pulled the words from her dream.
I trust you.
I miss him so much, she admitted.
Something special, warm and good happened between us.
Then there was a brief operational pause where we only spoke with our eyes or a soft touch.
He bid me farewell with a look that dove into my eyes as if trying to remember every feature of my face.
asking me not to worry and just explained it would take time.
How much time?
A month?
A year?
And above all, I'm like you.
Worried.
The hardest part is the unknown.
I dream about him at night.
In my dream I saw him sitting in a cafe in a foreign city with colonial buildings around, bearded with a strange hat.
He lifted his head and looked deep into my eyes, and I seemed to answer his question, saying, I trust you.
Just like you, I feel he's trying to convey to me from his depths not to worry that he's okay.
She lifted her eyes to Father David, feeling a bit teary from the emotions that seized her while speaking, not noticing the astonishment that seized him.
We need to send him back positive thoughts so that he won't worry about us either, so that he'll be calm and focused on whatever he's doing there.
So he can return to us safely.
And if I may request quickly to Father David gently stroked her hand.
He'll be okay.
And it's important for me to know you'll be okay too.
After a moment of silence, he added, I have to go back.
You have no idea how much Naomi will be pleased when I tell her I saw you and your pink house.
It's truly lovely here, and your dad's paintings on the walls are wonderful.
Do you see him?
Yes, at least every two weeks, and it's perfectly fine.
He's my special dad.
She was so happy with his visit.
There's something warm and familial about this big man, and she knew that both liked her very much, just as she liked them.
Yet she couldn't bring herself to say that maybe, just perhaps,
it would turn out that she was carrying their grandchild.
It was completely surreal, she thought.
It simply couldn't be.
After he left, she sat at the piano to calm herself, playing Misty.
Always knows how to do the work and tug at her heartstrings with its magnificent lyrics and enchanting melody.
On my own, would I wander through this wonderland alone?
Never knowing my right foot from my left, my hat from my glove.
I'm too misty and too much in love.
Alone, wandering my way through this wonderland alone, not knowing my right from my left, my hat from the glove on my hand.
Too misty and so much in love.
She was quiet, softly running her fingers over the keys.

pouring into the words that described everything she felt, murmuring them in her mind as she played, wishing he was beside her, giving her once more that wonderful feeling as if he was watching over her.
She would need to find some refuge from the fears, the unknown, the frustration of the long days that passed and would still pass.
She had to develop a defense mechanism like the one she developed after Lucy's death.
when she adopted the ability to divert troubling thoughts and not allow them to break through, even when they wish to do so.
